I have no doubt doubt animals mourn their dead. My Black Lab passed last year, and my Jack Russel didn’t handle it well. When my JR saw her best friend laying on the floor she walked up like usual to give him a nudge to wake him up, when he didn’t respond she looked at me(I was on the floor next to them, saying goodbye) and back at him a few times like she wanted me to wake him up. After a few seconds she started to nudge his nose with hers, getting faster and more forceful about it until she started doing it in a almost frantic manner, I saw the moment when she realized what was wrong and it was very clear and it broke my heart. When I tried to comfort her by petting her, she just laid down next him and wouldn’t move, and gave out a low crying sound. When I tried moving her to get him ready to put in the truck(took him to be cremated), she refused to move and while I was sitting down next to them she just crawled into my lap and laid there.

There was a definite mourning period, the JR is one of the happiest dogs I’ve known(my parents bred dogs while I was growing up so I’ve known a lot of dogs, both ours and others) and she is always cheerful and playful. For about 2 weeks she didn’t eat much, moved very slowly, wouldn’t play with me or with any of her toys, etc. Losing my Lab was heartbreaking enough for me, but seeing how it affected the JR made it so much worse. Even after she got passed it, it seemed difficult for her, being the only dog in the house for the first time in her life, so I made the extra effort every day to give her more attention and more love. About 6 months later my moms Labradoodle had puppies and I couldn’t pass up the chance to give my JR a friend, and finally after so long I get to see her at her happiest again. The labradoodle is now just 4 months old and while she can cross the line and play a bit too rough the JR seems to be in 7th heaven....

I've repeatedly seen housecats, my own and those I spend a lot of time with (family and close friends) mourn for the loss of a feline companion. In one case, my extremely playful loving cat stopped showing any interest in play and less interest in contact for quite a long time after his "big brother" passed away. He got over it months later, in large part because of another cat who showed up on the doorstep and they hit it off immediately. My other cat at the time showed no signs of grief and apparently wasn't close enough to the one mourning to make a difference. More recently, my hand-raised kitten acted oddly, very clingy and needy, for weeks after the adult female who helped me raise him died. Like humans, they have different personalities and therefore different relationships, and they show it in different ways. But they definitely can feel the loss.

By the way, lions eating a pride-mate doesn't necessarily mean they don't care. They run on the edge of survival so often that passing up a meal for sentimental reasons would be ridiculous. And corvids checking out the cause of death also does not preclude an emotional reaction to the death of a companion. Anthropomorphism is bad, but so is going too far the opposite direction.

Given the fact that emotions arise more from the hind brain it makes sense that many animals would mourn. The Cerebrum and other better developed areas in humans are actually more responsible for keeping our emotions in check and filtering them. Like with everything we humans do we mourn in complex social ways as well as simple emotional ones. Animals are less likely to display the complex rituals we perform because these arise as part of our culture and self consciousness. But the underlying emotions that are part of the mourning process, grief, depression, sadness, are very likely to be shared by many many of our closer cousins IMO.

I have observed many different animals mourn their dead companions. That answer is absolutely yes, many different species of animal mourn their dead. Just like the Human animal does. Animals within the same sub group vary just as much in personality as humans do, but scientists tend to ignore this depth of context in favor of an easily categorized box that sort of fits most of the time.

The truth is, one crow might eat a dead chick in the nest, and another might scream itself into feinting and die from falling out of the tree. One cat might eat a sick or dead kitten, where another might stop eating and drinking entirely and just die.

Horses will mourn the spot where a companion died long after the death, even other species like dogs, goats, and once I observed a horse visiting the place its owner died in the field and lying down every night for 43 nights. Until it became too cold to stay out at night he would lay there. That horse still sleeps in that spot whenever the whether is warm enough years later.

To suggest animals do not mourn their dead is preposterous. We are all animals. All of us. Four legged, two legged, aquatic, avian, etc... we are all the same thing, and we are all more similar than we are different.

Anyone who has had more than one pet can tell you that animals definitely are aware and react to the death of their companions. All of my cats (I've had 5 throughout my life,) have had distinct and varied behavioral changes when one of the others died. Some withdrew into isolation and refused to eat, some became much more needy and sought more attention, some searched every cranny of the house for their missing friend. The same is true of my dogs. When one of them died, the other became much more anxious, to the point where he could no longer handle being home alone.

My current cat was doing okay after my other cat died. I went to brush her a bit since she really likes it, but she smelled her brother's fur on the brush and instantly was off, searching for him again and yowling. Even now, a year later, if she sees one of the videos I recorded of him, she runs up to the screen and watches intently. If I say that cat's name, my dog's ear perk up and she excitedly turns to look at the spot where he always used to lay. Animals have memory, and they have emotions.

But that day Sarah had been sitting in a corner not doing much of anything. She refused to talk, or fly, any of her normal behaviors. After I found Gracie I told my manager and she came in and showed all the other cockatiels the body. They were a flock and you could tell this had an affect. The reactions were varied, some birds tried to wake her up, others started screaming and flying around, others still just sat there silent. Sarah was never the same. She was always sweet, but after Gracie died she became mean and violent towards people and other birds. It really goes to show just how intelligent and connected parrots can be.
